<a id="class_Vector4"></a>

# Vector4

A 4D vector using floating-point coordinates.

<!-- classref-introduction-group -->

## Description

A 4-element structure that can be used to represent 4D coordinates or any other quadruplet of numeric values.

It uses floating-point coordinates. By default, these floating-point values use 32-bit precision, unlike [float](class_float.md) which is always 64-bit. If double precision is needed, compile the engine with the option ``precision=double``.

See [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) for its integer counterpart.

\ **Note:** In a boolean context, a Vector4 will evaluate to ``false`` if it's equal to ``Vector4(0, 0, 0, 0)``. Otherwise, a Vector4 will always evaluate to ``true``.

<!-- classref-reftable-group -->

Enumerated value for the X axis. Returned by [max_axis_index()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_max_axis_index) and [min_axis_index()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_min_axis_index).<a id="class_Vector4_constant_AXIS_Y"></a>

Enumerated value for the Z axis. Returned by [max_axis_index()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_max_axis_index) and [min_axis_index()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_min_axis_index).<a id="class_Vector4_constant_AXIS_W"></a>

[Axis](class_vector4.md#enum_Vector4_Axis) **AXIS_W** = `3`

Enumerated value for the W axis. Returned by [max_axis_index()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_max_axis_index) and [min_axis_index()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_min_axis_index).<hr class="classref-section-separator">

## Constants

<a id="class_Vector4_constant_ZERO"></a>

<!-- classref-constant -->

**ZERO** = `Vector4(0, 0, 0, 0)` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_constant_ZERO)

Zero vector, a vector with all components set to ``0``.

<a id="class_Vector4_constant_ONE"></a>

<!-- classref-constant -->

**ONE** = `Vector4(1, 1, 1, 1)` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_constant_ONE)

One vector, a vector with all components set to ``1``.

<a id="class_Vector4_constant_INF"></a>

<!-- classref-constant -->

**INF** = `Vector4(inf, inf, inf, inf)` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_constant_INF)

Infinity vector, a vector with all components set to [@GDScript.INF](class_@gdscript.md#class_@GDScript_constant_INF).

## Method Descriptions

<a id="class_Vector4_method_abs"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **abs**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_abs)

Returns a new vector with all components in absolute values (i.e. positive).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_ceil"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **ceil**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_ceil)

Returns a new vector with all components rounded up (towards positive infinity).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_clamp"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **clamp**\ (\ min\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md), max\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_clamp)

Returns a new vector with all components clamped between the components of `min` and `max`, by running [@GlobalScope.clamp()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_clamp) on each component.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_clampf"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **clampf**\ (\ min\: [float](class_float.md), max\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_clampf)

Returns a new vector with all components clamped between `min` and `max`, by running [@GlobalScope.clamp()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_clamp) on each component.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_cubic_interpolate"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **cubic_interpolate**\ (\ b\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md), pre_a\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md), post_b\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md), weight\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_cubic_interpolate)

Performs a cubic interpolation between this vector and `b` using `pre_a` and `post_b` as handles, and returns the result at position `weight`. `weight` is on the range of 0.0 to 1.0, representing the amount of interpolation.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_cubic_interpolate_in_time"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **cubic_interpolate_in_time**\ (\ b\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md), pre_a\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md), post_b\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md), weight\: [float](class_float.md), b_t\: [float](class_float.md), pre_a_t\: [float](class_float.md), post_b_t\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_cubic_interpolate_in_time)

Performs a cubic interpolation between this vector and `b` using `pre_a` and `post_b` as handles, and returns the result at position `weight`. `weight` is on the range of 0.0 to 1.0, representing the amount of interpolation.

It can perform smoother interpolation than [cubic_interpolate()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_cubic_interpolate) by the time values.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_direction_to"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **direction_to**\ (\ to\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_direction_to)

Returns the normalized vector pointing from this vector to `to`. This is equivalent to using ``(b - a).normalized()``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_distance_squared_to"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **distance_squared_to**\ (\ to\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_distance_squared_to)

Returns the squared distance between this vector and `to`.

This method runs faster than [distance_to()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_distance_to), so prefer it if you need to compare vectors or need the squared distance for some formula.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_distance_to"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **distance_to**\ (\ to\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_distance_to)

Returns the distance between this vector and `to`.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_dot"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **dot**\ (\ with\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_dot)

Returns the dot product of this vector and `with`.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_floor"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **floor**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_floor)

Returns a new vector with all components rounded down (towards negative infinity).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_inverse"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **inverse**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_inverse)

Returns the inverse of the vector. This is the same as ``Vector4(1.0 / v.x, 1.0 / v.y, 1.0 / v.z, 1.0 / v.w)``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_is_equal_approx"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **is_equal_approx**\ (\ to\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_is_equal_approx)

Returns ``true`` if this vector and `to` are approximately equal, by running [@GlobalScope.is_equal_approx()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_is_equal_approx) on each component.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_is_finite"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **is_finite**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_is_finite)

Returns ``true`` if this vector is finite, by calling [@GlobalScope.is_finite()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_is_finite) on each component.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_is_normalized"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **is_normalized**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_is_normalized)

Returns ``true`` if the vector is normalized, i.e. its length is approximately equal to 1.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_is_zero_approx"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **is_zero_approx**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_is_zero_approx)

Returns ``true`` if this vector's values are approximately zero, by running [@GlobalScope.is_zero_approx()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_is_zero_approx) on each component.

This method is faster than using [is_equal_approx()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_is_equal_approx) with one value as a zero vector.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_length"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **length**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_length)

Returns the length (magnitude) of this vector.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_length_squared"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **length_squared**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_length_squared)

Returns the squared length (squared magnitude) of this vector.

This method runs faster than [length()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_length), so prefer it if you need to compare vectors or need the squared distance for some formula.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_lerp"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **lerp**\ (\ to\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md), weight\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_lerp)

Returns the result of the linear interpolation between this vector and `to` by amount `weight`. `weight` is on the range of ``0.0`` to ``1.0``, representing the amount of interpolation.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_max"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **max**\ (\ with\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_max)

Returns the component-wise maximum of this and `with`, equivalent to ``Vector4(maxf(x, with.x), maxf(y, with.y), maxf(z, with.z), maxf(w, with.w))``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_max_axis_index"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[int](class_int.md) **max_axis_index**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_max_axis_index)

Returns the axis of the vector's highest value. See ``AXIS_*`` constants. If all components are equal, this method returns [AXIS_X](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_constant_AXIS_X).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_maxf"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **maxf**\ (\ with\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_maxf)

Returns the component-wise maximum of this and `with`, equivalent to ``Vector4(maxf(x, with), maxf(y, with), maxf(z, with), maxf(w, with))``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_min"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **min**\ (\ with\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_min)

Returns the component-wise minimum of this and `with`, equivalent to ``Vector4(minf(x, with.x), minf(y, with.y), minf(z, with.z), minf(w, with.w))``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_min_axis_index"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[int](class_int.md) **min_axis_index**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_min_axis_index)

Returns the axis of the vector's lowest value. See ``AXIS_*`` constants. If all components are equal, this method returns [AXIS_W](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_constant_AXIS_W).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_minf"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **minf**\ (\ with\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_minf)

Returns the component-wise minimum of this and `with`, equivalent to ``Vector4(minf(x, with), minf(y, with), minf(z, with), minf(w, with))``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_normalized"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **normalized**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_normalized)

Returns the result of scaling the vector to unit length. Equivalent to ``v / v.length()``. Returns ``(0, 0, 0, 0)`` if ``v.length() == 0``. See also [is_normalized()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_is_normalized).

\ **Note:** This function may return incorrect values if the input vector length is near zero.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_posmod"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **posmod**\ (\ mod\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_posmod)

Returns a vector composed of the [@GlobalScope.fposmod()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_fposmod) of this vector's components and `mod`.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_posmodv"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **posmodv**\ (\ modv\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_posmodv)

Returns a vector composed of the [@GlobalScope.fposmod()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_fposmod) of this vector's components and `modv`'s components.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_round"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **round**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_round)

Returns a new vector with all components rounded to the nearest integer, with halfway cases rounded away from zero.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_sign"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **sign**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_sign)

Returns a new vector with each component set to ``1.0`` if it's positive, ``-1.0`` if it's negative, and ``0.0`` if it's zero. The result is identical to calling [@GlobalScope.sign()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_sign) on each component.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_snapped"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **snapped**\ (\ step\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_snapped)

Returns a new vector with each component snapped to the nearest multiple of the corresponding component in `step`. This can also be used to round the components to an arbitrary number of decimals.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_method_snappedf"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **snappedf**\ (\ step\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_method_snappedf)

Returns a new vector with each component snapped to the nearest multiple of `step`. This can also be used to round the components to an arbitrary number of decimals.

<hr class="classref-section-separator">

<!-- classref-descriptions-group -->

## Operator Descriptions

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_neq_Vector4"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator !=**\ (\ right\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_neq_Vector4)

Returns ``true`` if the vectors are not equal.

\ **Note:** Due to floating-point precision errors, consider using [is_equal_approx()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_is_equal_approx) instead, which is more reliable.

\ **Note:** Vectors with [@GDScript.NAN](class_@gdscript.md#class_@GDScript_constant_NAN) elements don't behave the same as other vectors. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_mul_Projection"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [Projection](class_projection.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_mul_Projection)

Transforms (multiplies) the **Vector4** by the transpose of the given [Projection](class_projection.md) matrix.

For transforming by inverse of a projection ``projection.inverse() * vector`` can be used instead. See [Projection.inverse()](class_projection.md#class_Projection_method_inverse).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_mul_Vector4"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_mul_Vector4)

Multiplies each component of the **Vector4** by the components of the given **Vector4**.

```
    print(Vector4(10, 20, 30, 40) * Vector4(3, 4, 5, 6)) # Prints (30.0, 80.0, 150.0, 240.0)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_mul_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_mul_float)

Multiplies each component of the **Vector4** by the given [float](class_float.md).

```
    print(Vector4(10, 20, 30, 40) * 2) # Prints (20.0, 40.0, 60.0, 80.0)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_mul_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [int](class_int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_mul_int)

Multiplies each component of the **Vector4** by the given [int](class_int.md).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_sum_Vector4"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **operator +**\ (\ right\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_sum_Vector4)

Adds each component of the **Vector4** by the components of the given **Vector4**.

```
    print(Vector4(10, 20, 30, 40) + Vector4(3, 4, 5, 6)) # Prints (13.0, 24.0, 35.0, 46.0)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_dif_Vector4"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **operator -**\ (\ right\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_dif_Vector4)

Subtracts each component of the **Vector4** by the components of the given **Vector4**.

```
    print(Vector4(10, 20, 30, 40) - Vector4(3, 4, 5, 6)) # Prints (7.0, 16.0, 25.0, 34.0)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_div_Vector4"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **operator /**\ (\ right\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_div_Vector4)

Divides each component of the **Vector4** by the components of the given **Vector4**.

```
    print(Vector4(10, 20, 30, 40) / Vector4(2, 5, 3, 4)) # Prints (5.0, 4.0, 10.0, 10.0)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_div_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **operator /**\ (\ right\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_div_float)

Divides each component of the **Vector4** by the given [float](class_float.md).

```
    print(Vector4(10, 20, 30, 40) / 2) # Prints (5.0, 10.0, 15.0, 20.0)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_div_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **operator /**\ (\ right\: [int](class_int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_div_int)

Divides each component of the **Vector4** by the given [int](class_int.md).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_lt_Vector4"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator <**\ (\ right\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_lt_Vector4)

Compares two **Vector4** vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is less than the X value of the `right` vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors, Z values of the two vectors, and then with the W values. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

\ **Note:** Vectors with [@GDScript.NAN](class_@gdscript.md#class_@GDScript_constant_NAN) elements don't behave the same as other vectors. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_lte_Vector4"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator <=**\ (\ right\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_lte_Vector4)

Compares two **Vector4** vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is less than or equal to the X value of the `right` vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors, Z values of the two vectors, and then with the W values. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

\ **Note:** Vectors with [@GDScript.NAN](class_@gdscript.md#class_@GDScript_constant_NAN) elements don't behave the same as other vectors. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_eq_Vector4"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator ==**\ (\ right\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_eq_Vector4)

Returns ``true`` if the vectors are exactly equal.

\ **Note:** Due to floating-point precision errors, consider using [is_equal_approx()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_is_equal_approx) instead, which is more reliable.

\ **Note:** Vectors with [@GDScript.NAN](class_@gdscript.md#class_@GDScript_constant_NAN) elements don't behave the same as other vectors. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_gt_Vector4"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator >**\ (\ right\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_gt_Vector4)

Compares two **Vector4** vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is greater than the X value of the `right` vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors, Z values of the two vectors, and then with the W values. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

\ **Note:** Vectors with [@GDScript.NAN](class_@gdscript.md#class_@GDScript_constant_NAN) elements don't behave the same as other vectors. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_gte_Vector4"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator >=**\ (\ right\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_gte_Vector4)

Compares two **Vector4** vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is greater than or equal to the X value of the `right` vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors, Z values of the two vectors, and then with the W values. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

\ **Note:** Vectors with [@GDScript.NAN](class_@gdscript.md#class_@GDScript_constant_NAN) elements don't behave the same as other vectors. Therefore, the results from this operator may not be accurate if NaNs are included.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_idx_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[float](class_float.md) **operator []**\ (\ index\: [int](class_int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_idx_int)

Access vector components using their `index`. ``v[0]`` is equivalent to ``v.x``, ``v[1]`` is equivalent to ``v.y``, ``v[2]`` is equivalent to ``v.z``, and ``v[3]`` is equivalent to ``v.w``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_unplus"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **operator unary+**\ (\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_unplus)

Returns the same value as if the ``+`` was not there. Unary ``+`` does nothing, but sometimes it can make your code more readable.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4_operator_unminus"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **operator unary-**\ (\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4_operator_unminus)

Returns the negative value of the **Vector4**. This is the same as writing ``Vector4(-v.x, -v.y, -v.z, -v.w)``. This operation flips the direction of the vector while keeping the same magnitude. With floats, the number zero can be either positive or negative.
